title: Erdős #546: Ramsey Numbers and Edge Count
description: For a graph G with no isolated vertices and m edges, is R(G) ≤ 2^{O(√m)}? Solved by Sudakov (2011). The ≥3 color version remains open.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem in 1984, asking whether the Ramsey number of a graph G with m edges is at most exponential in √m. Sudakov proved this in 2011. Earlier, Alon-Krivelevich-Sudakov (2003) proved the bipartite case. The multi-color version (≥3 colors) remains open.
overview.problemStatement: Let G be a graph with no isolated vertices and m edges. Is R(G) ≤ 2^{O(√m)}? This asks whether the Ramsey number grows at most exponentially in the square root of the edge count.
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the Ramsey number definition, Sudakov's theorem, the bipartite case (AKS 2003), the multi-color generalization (open), and specific graph classes (paths, cycles, complete bipartite). We also formalize the connection to Problem #545.
keyInsights: Sudakov (2011): R(G) ≤ 2^{O(√m)} for all graphs G with m edges
Sparse graphs (paths, cycles): R is linear, much better than √m bound
Connection to Problem #545: More precise exponent question

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #546 on Ramsey numbers and edge count. Sudakov (2011) proved R(G) ≤ 2^{O(√m)}, solving the 2-color case. The bipartite case was proved earlier by AKS (2003). The analogous question for ≥3 colors remains open.
conclusion.implications: This result connects graph structure (edge count) to Ramsey-theoretic complexity. It shows that graphs with few edges have relatively small Ramsey numbers, which has applications in extremal graph theory.
openQuestions: Does R_r(G) ≤ 2^{O(√m)} hold for r ≥ 3 colors?
What is the precise constant in Sudakov's bound?
Can the bound be improved for specific graph families?
